Summary: The proposal aims to integrate hierarchical symbolic planning with reinforcement learning (RL) for robust robotic autonomy in dynamic environments. It introduces a three-tiered architecture with a symbolic planner, neural latent interface, and RL policy, enabling bidirectional communication. The experiment plan includes validation, benchmarking, real-world deployment, ablation studies, and scalability testing.
Strengths: Innovative hypothesis with a novel latent space interface for bidirectional communication.
Detailed and structured method with a three-tiered architecture.
Comprehensive experiment plan covering validation, benchmarking, and real-world deployment.
Strong problem statement highlighting the limitations of existing methods.
Weaknesses: Lack of detailed discussion on technical challenges (e.g., computational overhead, robustness under extreme noise).
Uncertainty about the feasibility of bidirectional adaptation in real-time.
Ambiguous real-world deployment specifics, especially for handling unforeseen adversarial perturbations.
Baseline comparisons could be more comprehensive (e.g., including recent hybrid methods).
Questions: How will the system handle extreme environmental noise or sensor failures in the latent space alignment?
What are the computational overheads of the VAE and GNN-based MPC controller, and how will they be optimized?
Can the bidirectional adaptation scale to high-dimensional action spaces in real-time?
What specific adversarial perturbations will be tested in the real-world deployment, and how will the system recover from them?
Limitations: Potential high computational overhead of the neural latent interface.
Uncertain robustness of the latent space alignment under extreme noise.
Scalability challenges in high-dimensional or multi-robot scenarios.
Dependence on simulation-to-real transfer for training efficiency.
